metadata.title: Synthesis of carbon nano-onion embedded metal–organic frameworks as an efficient adsorbent for cadmium ions: kinetic and thermodynamic studies

sections.text: Keywords Carbon nano-onions .MOF-199 . Characterization . Adsorption . Kinetic . Thermodynamic

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Carbon atoms have a unique ability to form a wide range of carbon structures ranged from long-chain molecules to small ones due to the ability of carbon atom to form strong covalent bonds with other carbon atoms in different hybridization forms (SP3, SP2, and SP). Carbon nanostructures are used in different applications (Ghalkhani et al. 2019; Hu et al. 2019; Lim et al. 2019; Hong-Shan et al. 2019; Shang et al. 2019). Carbon nanostructure can be classified according to the type of covalent bonds into different classes. The first class
involves graphitic carbon structure made up of sp2 carbon atoms and includes carbon nanotubes, graphene nanosheets, nanohornes, graphene, carbon nanospheres, carbon dots, and carbon nano-onions. The second type of carbon nanostructure is formed due to the presence of sp3 and sp2 carbon atoms with different ratios, and it is not built from monolayer graphene forms such as nanodiamond. Another classification for carbon nanostructure is based on empty space nanoforms such as nanohornes, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), and fullerene while carbon nano-onions (CNOs), carbon dots (C-dots), nanodiamond, and graphene were considered as a second morphological type without internal spaces (Georgakilas et al. 2015). CNOs are spherical shells separated from each other by 0.334 nm as graphitic separation planes. CNOs were used in different fields of applications such as biological applications (Giordani et al. 2014), catalysis (Shi et al. 2016), energy storage (Ratajczak et al. 2019), anti-adhesion (Liang et al. 2018), electronics (Olariu et al. 2017), conversion of energy (Plonska-Brzezinska and Echegoyen 2013), sensors (Wu et al. 2010), hyper lubricants (Joly-Pottuz et al. 2010), and adsorption (Megan et al. 2012; Sakulthaew et al. 2015; Yu Responsible editor: Tito Roberto Cadaval Jr Electronic supplementary material The online version of this article (https://doi.org/10.1007/s11356-019-05581-5) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users. * Asaad F. Hassan asmz68@sci.dmu.edu.eg; asmz68@yahoo.com 1 Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, University of Damanhour, Damanhour, Egypt
et al. 2016; Sakulthaew et al. 2017). Many disadvantages for carbon nanomaterial (CNM) applications include the difficulty in separation of CNMs after treatment, toxicity effects in plants and terrestrial including ecosystem effects on epigenetics, gene expression, oxidative stress (Jordan et al. 2018), and the ability to form larger particles due to aggregations. Attempts were introduced to enhance the application conditions of CNMs such as the formation of C-dots/chitosan composite (Wang et al. 2015), composites of carbon nano-onions with emeraldine polyaniline (Plonska-Brzezinska et al. 2012), and carbon nanomaterial modified metal–organic frameworks (Xu et al. 2016; Farid et al. 2018).
Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are highly porous crystalline hybrid materials prepared from the interaction between the metal ions and multidentate organic compounds forming a three-dimensional structure characterized by high surface areas, up to 5200 m2 g−1 (Ben et al. 2009). Currently, MOFs have been the subjects of many application fields such as adsorption (Wang et al. 2017), catalysis (Wang and Li 2017), energy storage (Zhang et al. 2018), storage of gas (Li et al. 2018), drug delivery (Ke et al. 2018), and optics (Du and Zhang 2013).
Cadmium is a highly toxic heavy metal causing pancreatic cancer, renal failure (Davis et al. 2006), osteoporosis (Xu et al. 2014), hypertension (Gallagher and Meliker 2010), and diabetes (Edwards and Prozialeck 2009). Cadmium is still used in different industries such as solar photocatalysis (Giacopetti and Satta 2018), yellow pigments (Kamran et al. 2017; Bilgin et al. 2018), phosphatic fertilizers, metal coating, batteries, plastics, and incineration of solid wastes containing cadmium (Fei et al. 2018). Various methods have been applied in cadmium removal from aqueous medium including ion exchange, solvent extraction, chemical precipitation, coagulation, adsorption, flotation, and membrane process. Adsorption is still one of the most efficient, simplest, and fastest methods for the removal of organic and inorganic pollutants fromwater (Bashir et al. 2018).
The aim of the present work is the preparation of metal–organic frameworks (MOF-199), CNOs, and carbon nanoonion embedded MOF-199 (CMOF-199) for adsorption of cadmium ions from the aqueous medium under different application conditions.

sections.heading: Materials
sections.text:
Cadmium chloride (99.99%), Cu (NO3)2·3H2O (99.98%), and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (95%) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co. Ltd., and other reagents were obtained from El-Nasr for Pharmaceutical and Chemical Industrial
Co., Egypt. All reagents were used without further purification.

sections.heading: Preparation of solid adsorbents
sections.text:
MOF-199 (Cu2 (C9H3O6)4/3) was prepared by using a method described by Britt et al. (2008) with slight modifications. In a round bottle flask containing a solvent mixture of distilled water (2 ml), ethanol (4 ml), and DMF (3 ml), a solid mixture of 0.438 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 0.236 g of 1,3,5- benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) was dissolved. The round bottle flask was heated for 24 h at 85 °C to give the light blue crystals. The produced solid crystals were cooled at room temperature and washed with DMF several times after separation by centrifugation at 3000 rpm. The previous solid products were washed with ethanol and dried at 150 °C and kept as deep purple crystals (MOF-199).
CNO was prepared from garlic peels as a green carbon source (Ahmed et al. 2016). Garlic peels were washed with deionized water several times, dried at 80 °C, and grinded into small pieces. A certain weight of the dried sample (40 g) was mixed with 5 ml of NaOH (30% w/v) in a crucible. The crucible with the mixture was transferred into muffle and heated at 250 °C for 3 h till the formation of brownish yellow solid material. The solid material was dispersed in 100ml deionized water and filtered through 40-ml gooch crucible and filtered through a 0.45-μm nylon filter. The filtrate was purified through dialyzer tube at room temperature (MWCO, 3.5 kDa) for 5 days. Then, the purified solution was dried at 50 °C under vacuum and stored in a closed sample tube (CNO).
Carbon nano-onion embedded MOF-199 was synthesized by dispersing of 0.01 g CNO in a mixture of distilled water (2 ml), ethanol (4 ml), and DMF (3 ml) using magnetic stirrer for 30 min. Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (0.438 g) and 0.236 g of 1,3,5- benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BTC) were added to the previous solution. The next steps were applied as in the case of MOF-199 preparation to yield CMOF-199.

sections.heading: Characterization of solid adsorbents
sections.text:
Thermogravimetric analysis was applied by using a differential thermal analyzer (Shimadzu DTA-50, Japan) from room temperature up to 1000 °C. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption parameters were determined using a NOVA2000 gas sorption analyzer (Quantachrome Corporation, USA). XRD patterns (2θ in the range 5–80°) were applied on powdered samples using PANalytical X’Pert PRO and Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 A°), and the tube was operated at 30 kV. Debye– Scherrer average particle size (Ps, nm) was calculated using the following equation:
Ps nmð Þ ¼ λk βCosθ
ð1Þ
where X-ray wavelength (λ) = 0.15418 nm, k equals 0.9, and β is the full width at 0.5 peak height. TEM (transmission electron microscopy) and EDX (energy-dispersive X-ray spectra) were studied by a JEOL-JEM-2100 (Tokyo, Japan) at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. FTIR (Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy) was investigated in the range between 400 and 4000 cm−1 by a Mattson 5000 FTIR spectrometer. Point of zero charge (pHPZC) for MOF-199, CNO, and CMOF-199 was determined as follows: initially, 20 ml of 0.01 M NaCl solutions was added into several flasks. The pH in each flask was adjusted to pH values ranged between 2 and 12 by 0.05 M solution of NaOH and/or HCl. Solid sample (0.10 g) was added to each flask followed by agitation for 24 h, and the final pH value was measured using Hanna pH meter HI 110. pHPZC is the point at which pHfinal = pHinitial (Foo and Hameed 2012; Hassan et al. 2017).

sections.heading: Adsorption of cadmium ions
sections.text:
The adsorption of Cd+2 from aqueous solution by MOF-199, CNO, and CMOF-199 was investigated by shaking of 20 ml of 100 mg l−1 Cd+2 solution with 0.02 g of solid adsorbent at 20 °C for 3 h. After 3 h, the solution was centrifuged at 2000 rpm and filtered through 0.45-μm syringe filter membrane. The equilibrium cadmium concentrations were determined by GBC Sens. AAS (Dandenong, Victoria 3175, Australia), and every measurement was repeated three times. Different adsorption conditions were carried out to study the effects of adsorbent dosage (0.25–1.5 g l−1), pH (2–8), time (5–120 min), initial cadmium ion concentration (10– 150 mg l−1), and adsorption temperature (20, 30, and 40 °C). Removal percent was calculated using the following equation:
R% ¼ Co−Ce Co 100 ð2Þ
where Co and Ce are the initial and equilibrium concentrations of Cd+2 solutions, respectively.

sections.heading: Langmuir isotherm
sections.text:
It assumes that monolayer adsorption occurs at a finite number of identical and equivalent localized sites. The linear model of the Langmuir equation (Langmuir 1916) is derived as
Ce qe ¼ 1 bqm þ Ce qm
ð3Þ
where qe and qm are adsorption capacity at equilibrium and the maximum adsorption capacity (mg g−1), respectively, while b is Langmuir adsorption constant (l mg−1). The adsorption capacity was calculated using the following relation:
qe ¼ Co−Ce
w V ð4Þ
where Vand w are the volume (l) and the mass of solid adsorbent in grams, respectively.

sections.heading: Freundlich isotherm
sections.text:
Freundlich isotherm describes the reversible and non-ideal adsorption process (Freundlich 1906). The linear Freundlich model can be presented as
lnqe ¼ ln K F þ 1
n
ln Ce ð5Þ
Herein, KF and n are the Freundlich constants and are related to the adsorption capacity and intensity of adsorption, respectively.

sections.heading: Temkin isotherm
sections.text:
Temkin isotherm postulates that the heat of adsorption of all molecules in the layer would decrease linearly with surface coverage due to adsorbent–adsorbate interactions (Foo and Hameed 2012). It also assumes an equal distribution of bounding energy up to some maximum bonding energy. The linear model is expressed by the following equation (Inyinbor et al. 2016):
qe ¼ AKT þ A Ln Ce ð6Þ
A ¼ RT bT
ð7Þ
where A is a constant related to the heat of adsorption, bT is the Temkin constant (J mol−1), R is the gas constant (8.314, J mol−1 K−1), T is the absolute adsorption temperature in Kelvin, and KT is Temkin isotherm constant (l g −1).

sections.heading: Dubinin–Radhushkevich isotherm
sections.text:
The adsorption phenomenon at heterogeneous and homogeneous surfaces was described by Dubinin–Radhushkevich model (D–R) with the following linear form:
Ln qe ¼ Ln qDR−KDRε2 ð8Þ
ε ¼ RTLn 1þ 1 Ce
ð9Þ
Herein, qDR (mg g −1) is the maximum adsorption capacity, ɛ is the Polanyi potential parameter, and KDR is the activity coefficient (mol2 kJ−2). R is the gas adsorption constant (8.314 J mol−1 K−1), and T is the absolute adsorption temperature in Kelvin. The mean adsorption energy (EDR, kJ mol
−1) can be calculated by the following equation (Banerjee and Chattopadhyaya 2017):
EDR ¼ 1ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi 2KDR p ð10Þ

sections.heading: Adsorption kinetic models
sections.text:
The adsorption kinetic rates were discussed by the applications of Lagergren and Svenska pseudo-first (PFO) and pseudo-second (PSO) kinetic models (Eqs. 11 and 12), respectively.
ln qe−qtð Þ ¼ ln qeð Þ−k1t ð11Þ t qt ¼ 1 k2qe2 þ 1 qe t ð12Þ
where qt (mg g −1) is the adsorption capacity after time intervals and was determined by Eq. 13. The rate constants of PFO and PSOmodels are k1 (min −1) and k2 (g mg −1 min−1), respectively
qt ¼ Co−Ctð ÞV
w ð13Þ
where Ct (mg l −1) is the equilibrium concentration of Cd+2 at time t.

sections.heading: Thermodynamic studies
sections.text:
Thermodynamic parameters like the change in free energy (ΔG°), entropy (ΔS°), and enthalpy (ΔH°) were calculated for the adsorption of Cd+2 by MOF-199, CNO, and CMOF199 at different adsorption temperature values (20, 30, and 40 °C). The following equations were used to calculate the thermodynamic parameters: Kd ¼ CsCe ð14Þ
Ln Kd ¼ ΔS°R − ΔH° RT
ð15Þ ΔG° ¼ ΔH°−TΔS° ð16Þ where Kd, Cs (mg l −1), and Ce (mg l −1) are the adsorption distribution coefficient, surface adsorbed, and the equilibrium concentrations of Cd+2, respectively. R is the gas constant, and T is the absolute adsorption temperature. Van’t Hoff plot (Eq. 15) was used to calculate ΔS° and ΔH° from the intercept and slope.

sections.heading: Characterization of solid adsorbents
sections.text:
Thermogravimetric analysis curves for MOF-199, CNO, and CMOF-199 are presented in Fig. 1a. MOF-199, CNO, and CMOF-199 showed weight loss about 2.7, 0.9, and 6.3, respectively, at 120 °C. It is related to adsorbed water molecule evaporation indicating enhanced adsorption properties of CMOF-199 due to the incorporation between polar functional groups fromCNO and the higher surface area fromMOF-199. CNO showed thermal stability up to 620 °C, and the weight loss at 800 °C (about 89%) may be related to the oxidation of surface graphitic curved layers and thermal decomposition continued till 98% at about 1000 °C due to core oxidation of the spheres (Zhang 2006). MOF-199 predicted the second stage of decomposition at 250–350 °C with weight loss of about 59% which may be related to –OH and a portion of organic framework decomposition (Ghiamaty et al. 2016) and that also coincides with the presence of 88% 1,3,5- benzenetricarboxylic acid as MOF-199 constituent. The residual part fromMOF-199 at a higher temperature may be related to copper oxide. CMOF-199 shows a thermal stability behavior lies between MOF-199 and CNO.
Textural parameters are important characterization method for any solid adsorbents. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms for all the investigated solid samples are displayed in Fig. 1b. CNO exhibited a type IV adsorption isotherm with observable hysteresis loop at higher relative pressure indicating the presence of mesopores and microspores in the synthesized CNO sample (Han et al. 2011). MOF-199 and CMOF199 showed type I adsorption isotherms with small hysteresis loops at the end of the plateau. The small hysteresis loop may be related to the presence of open cavities on the surface (Mahadi et al. 2015). Total surface area, pore volume, and pore radius are collected in Table 1. Data in Table 1 showed that textural parameters for MOF-199 and CMOF-199 are higher compared with CNO. SBET (m 2 g−1) and VP (cm 2 g−1) for the prepared solid materials increase in the orderMOF-199 > CMOF-199 > CNO. Incorporation of CNO amount in CMOF-199 reduces its surface area by about 9.4% which may be related to the blocking of some internal pores.
XRD patterns are important techniques for the characterization of nanomaterial. Figure 1c displays XRD analysis for all the samples. CNO provided the main peak at 2θ angle values of 25.9° (002) and can be related to the diffraction of hexagonal structure of graphite, and the indistinguishable twoband broadening at 43.1° (100 and 101) confirms the disordered structure of the prepared CNO due to its tiny sizes (Han et al. 2011). MOF-199 and CMOF-199 exhibited the same XRD peaks with a small change in peak intensities indicating that the introduction of CNO into MOF-199 does not affect the crystalline structures of the produced CMOF-199 solid
material. MOF-199 and CMOF-199 showed its characteristic peaks at 6.9, 9.5, 11.7, 13.5, 17.5, and 19.1° as reported in previous works (Wang et al. 2002; Tranchemontagne et al. 2008). Debye–Scherrer average particle size (Ps) were found to be 1.882, 2.830, and 2.890 nm for CNO, MOF-199, and CMOF-199, respectively.
A surface chemical function group for solid adsorbents is an important factor in the adsorption of heavy metal cations. Figure 1d displays the FTIR spectra for CNO, MOF-199, and CMOF-199. The broad peak located at around 3447 cm−1 for all the three samples is related to free O–H group stretching vibrations from C–OH, COOH, and H2O. CNO showed bands at 2890, 1646, 1460, and 1353 cm−1 which can be related to C–H symmetric stretching vibration, stretching vibrations of C=C, semicircle stretch of aromatic rings (Hassan and Elhadidy 2019), and δSC –O –H absorption (Ahmed et al. 2016),
respectively. The bands at 1097 cm−1 can be related to C– O stretching. MOF-199 showed low intensity bands at 765, 726, and 480 cm−1 which are related to out and inplane bending modes of –COO− group. The presence of organic ligand (H3BTC) in MOF-199 can be proved by the appearance of sharp bands at 768, 1251, 1452, and 1630 cm−1 which are related to C–H bending vibrations and C=C stretching vibration of the aromatic benzene ring (Fang et al. 2017). CMOF-199 and MOF-199 spectra are the same with a slight decrease in peak intensity in the case of CMOF-199 indicating that CNO spheres are entrapped in MOF-199 structure especially that FTIR discusses the surface function groups only. It is known that pH of point of zero charge (pHPZC) is the point at which the net surface charge equals to zero, while at pH > pHPZC, the surface accesses a negative charge and raises the adsorption capacity for cationic species. The measured
pHPZC values for MOF-199, CNO, and CMOF-199 are listed in Table 1 and found to be 4.8, 5.9, and 5.1, respectively.
Figure 2a HRTEM image of CNO showed that CNO nanoparticles formed of laminated concentric curved layers of graphene with about 5 nm in length. Small particles are aggregated with observable hollow interiors. The interlayer distances of 0.34 nm correspond to graphite plane (002) and the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (insert in a) reveals the poor graphitization of the CNO (Han et al. 2011). HRTEM of MOF-199 and CMOF-199 (c, e) indicated the presence of highly porous structures as reported by previous works (Mahadi et al. 2015), and the inserted SAED proved the crystalline nature of samples. EDX analysis for CNO (b) showed that
94.2% of the surface atoms are carbon atoms, and 39.7% in MOF-199 (d) is related to copper atoms while in the case of CMOF-199, the percentage of carbon atoms (f) increased to 56.8% with CNO incorporation. The presence of small traces of silicon impurities (0.1–0.7%) may be related to the preparation steps

sections.heading: Effect of adsorbent dosage
sections.text:
Adsorbent dosage is an important factor in studying the efficiency of adsorbate–adsorbent interaction due to the direct adsorption dependence on the number of active sites present
on the surface of solid adsorbents. Figure 3a shows the effect of adsorbent mass (0.005, 0.010, 0.015, 0.020, 0.025, and 0.030 g) on the removal percentage (R %, Eq. 2) using 20 ml of 100 mg l−1 Cd+2 solutions, after 3 h of shaking time and at 20 °C. It is evident that MOF-199, CNO, and CMOF199 have the same adsorption behavior. The removal percentage values were found to increase gradually with the increase in adsorbent dosage up to 0.75 g l−1 which can be related to the increase in the number of active sites responsible for the adsorption process. At adsorbent dosage > 0.75 g l−1, there is no observable increase in the removal percentage which can be related to adsorption equilibrium establishment at an extremely lower Cd+2 concentration. Based on the obtained results, 0.75 g l−1 has been chosen as the optimum value as the adsorbent dosage in the next experiments.

sections.heading: Effect of pH
sections.text:
The initial pH of adsorbate solution plays an important role in the adsorption of cations by solid adsorbents where it changes the chemistry of solid surface functional groups and the nature of adsorbate ions. Figure 3b presents the effect of pH on the adsorption of cadmium ion at different pH values (2–8). It was studied at 20 °C, 0.75 g l−1 adsorbent dosage, 3 h as contact shaking time, and 20 ml of 100 mg l−1 of Cd+2 solution. At lower pH values, the R% of Cd+2 is low which may be related to the protonation of active sites on the solid surface of adsorbents (Sohrabi 2014). In the case of MOF-199, raising pH values from 2 to 4 was accompanied by an increase in R % by about 99% while CNO and CMOF-199 exhibited an increase by about 62 and 47% with pH increase from 2 to 5. That increase in R % with pH increase may be related to the decrease in protonation of active sites on solid adsorbents and
more favorable adsorption condition. Cadmium ions present in aqueous solution in different forms including Cd+2, Cd(OH)+, Cd(OH)2, Cd(OH)3 −, Cd(OH)4 −2, and Cd(OH) –3, based on the solution pH value where at higher pH values, Cd+2 decreases dramatically. At pH > pHPZC, the decrease in adsorption of cadmium may be also related to the repulsion between the negatively charged solid surface and negatively charged cadmium complex ions (Moradi et al. 2016; Yusof et al. 2018). pH = 5 as initial adsorbate solution was chosen as the most suitable condition for the adsorption of Cd+2 onto the investigated solid adsorbents.
Effect of initial Cd+2 concentrations and adsorption isotherms
The adsorption isotherm reflects relation between the amounts of solute adsorbed (mg g−1) per unit weight of solid adsorbents and the residual concentration of adsorbate in solution (mg l−1) at a given temperature and after certain equilibrium time. Figure 4a–c depicts the adsorption isotherms for Cd+2 onto MOF-199, CNO, and CMOF-199, respectively, using 10–150 mg l−1 as initial adsorbate concentration, 0.75 g l−1 adsorbent dosage, pH 5, 40min as equilibrium time, and at 20, 30, and 40 °C. The adsorption data were analyzed by Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin, and Dubinin–Radhushkevich models (Eqs. 3, 5, 6, and 8, respectively).
Figure 5a–c shows the linear Langmuir model for the adsorption of Cd+2 byMOF-199, CNO, and CMOF-199, respectively, at 20, 30, and 40 °C while Freundlich linear plots are shown in Figure S1. Langmuir and Freundlich adsorption parameters are shown in Table 2. Adsorption of Cd+2 on MOF199, CNO, and CMOF-19 has fit well the Langmuir
adsorption model rather than the Freundlich model based on the higher R2 calculated from the application of the Langmuir model (0.9862–0.9998). This can be related to the homogeneous distribution of active sites on solid adsorbent surfaces (Li et al. 2016). The maximum adsorption capacities were achieved by CMOF-199 which can be related to the incorporation of rich chemical functional groups present on CNOwith higher surface area and porous nature from MOF-199 in
CMOF-199. It is observed that the maximum adsorption capacities for CMOF-199 > CNO > MOF-199 and the adsorption increase with temperature in all cases indicating the endothermic adsorption process.
Temkin plots for the adsorption of Cd+2 onto MOF-199, CNO, and CMOF-199 at 20, 30, and 40 °C are shown in Figure S2 while Temkin parameters are illustrated in Table 2. The Temkin model enables the calculation of KT
(equilibrium binding constant) belonging to the maximum energy of binding. The calculated KT values increase with temperature which means that the adsorption of Cd+2 onto the solid adsorbents is endothermic and favored at a higher temperature (Aljeboree et al. 2017) while the higher correlation coefficient values indicate the good applications of Temkin model.
Dubinin–Radushkevich model is more general than the Langmuir adsorption model because it considers the adsorption on homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces. The values of Dubinin–Radushkevich parameters are given in Table 2, and the linear plots for Cd+2 adsorption on MOF-199, CNO, and CMOF-199 at 20, 30, and 40 °C are shown in Figure S3. The adsorption potential depends on the nature of adsorbent and adsorbate rather than the adsorption temperature. The mean adsorption energy (EDR, kJ mol
−1) can be used to determine the adsorption nature if it is physical or chemical ion exchange. In the case of EDR between 8 and 16 kJ mol
−1, the adsorption is chemical ion exchange process and the physical adsorption force proved when EDR less than 8 kJ mol −1 (Rafatullah et al. 2009; Banerjee and Chattopadhyaya 2017). In the present work, EDR values ranged between 3.144 and 4.899 kJ mol−1 suggesting the physical adsorption at all the investigated temperatures. The correlation coefficients presented in Table 2 indicate that the adsorption of cadmium ion from aqueous solution best fitted the Langmuir, Temkin, and Dubinin–Radushkevich adsorption models.
Effect of agitation time and kinetic studies
The effect of shaking time and adsorption kinetic studies of Cd+2 onto MOF-199, CNO, and CMOF-199 was investigated by adding 0.1 g of solid adsorbent to 100ml of 200mg l−1 Cd+ 2 at pH = 5 and 20 °C with different contact times in the range 5–120 min. After each time interval, 1.0 ml of clear solution was removed to determine the equilibrium of Cd+2 concentrations. Figure 6a shows the effect of shaking time on the adsorption capacity. The rate of Cd+2 adsorption is higher at the beginning time of adsorption due to the presence of available active sites on the solid adsorbents. Adsorption equilibrium time was achieved after 40 min in the case of CMOF-199 and CNOwhile after 60min in the case ofMOF-199. Based on the previous experiment, 60 min was chosen as the equilibrium adsorption time for all the used solid adsorbents. Figure 6b shows the PSO plot (Eq. 12) for cadmium ion adsorption onto all the solid adsorbents while PFO plots (Eq. 11) are shown in Figure S4. PFO and PSO kinetic model parameters are listed in Table 3. Table 3 results showed that (i) the adsorption of Cd+2 onto MOF-199, CNO, and CMOF-199 fitted best into PSO kinetic models due to its higher correlation coefficient values (0.97153–0.99844) and the small difference between the experimental adsorption capacity (qexp) and the calculated values (qe). (ii) The correlation coefficient values calculated using PFO are small (0.81953–0.87547), and a large difference between the calculated and experimental adsorption capacities was observed which prove that cadmium adsorption onto the present solid materials does not follow PFO kinetic models. (iii) The pseudo-second-order rate constant (k2) values for MOF-199, CNO, and CMOF-199 are 6.05 × 10−4, 18.60 × 10−4, and 14.68 × 10−4 g mg−1 min−1, respectively, indicating the adsorption rate for CNO > CMOF-199 > MOF-199 which can be related to the abundance of active surface groups on the surface of carbon materials (Hassan and Bulánek 2018).

sections.heading: Thermodynamic studies
sections.text:
Thermodynamic parameters are collected in Table 4. The results from Table 4 shows that (i) positive entropy changes for Cd+2 adsorption by all the solid adsorbents ranged between 0.0196 and 0.0545 kJ mol−1 K−1 indicating the increased
Adsorbents R2 ΔH° (kJ mol−1) ΔS° (kJ mol−1 K−1) – ΔG° (kJ mol−1)
20 °C 30 °C 40 °C
randomness of Cd+2 at the solid/solution interface during the adsorption process (Agarwal et al. 2016). (ii) The negative values for free energy changes (ΔG°) confirm the spontaneous favorable adsorption of Cd+2 onto all the used solid adsorbents at all the investigated temperature. (iii) Free energy change va lues ranged between − 0 .4005 and − 4.3129 kJ mol−1 belong to physisorption process where it is known that chemisorption occurs when the free energy changes in the range − 80 and − 400 kJ mol−1 while physisorption in the range − 20 and 0 kJ mol−1 (Hassan et al. 2014). The increase in negative values for free energy changes increases with temperature, suggesting the more favorable adsorption process at a higher temperature. ΔG° values for CMOF-199 > CNO > MOF-199 may be related to the more spontaneous favorable adsorption of cadmium ion onto CMOF-199 compared with the other two adsorbents. (iv) The higher correlation coefficient values (R2) for linear application of Van’t Hoff plot (> 0.9916) indicating the good application of Van’t Hoff equation (Fig. 7). (v) The positive values for enthalpy changes (ΔH°) confirm the endothermic nature for cadmium adsorption onto MOF-199, CNO, and CMOF-199.
Comparison of CMOF-199 with other nanosolid adsorbents
To evaluate the efficiency of the recent solid adsorbents for removal of Cd+2 through adsorption process, the maximum adsorption capacity and adsorption conditions for CMOF-199 were compared with other reported solid adsorbents (Kataria and Garg 2018; Luo et al. 2013; Chen et al. 2014; Megan et al. 2012; Chen et al. 2018; Gupta and Nayak 2012; Lia et al. 2003) published in previous articles (Table 5). Data in Table 5 shows that CMOF-199 is a well better adsorbent for cadmium ions from aqueous solution compared with the other adsorbents. The higher adsorption capacity for CMOF-199 may be related to the incorporation of higher surface porosity for MOF-199 and the presence of surface functional groups from carbon nano-onions.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: The present study showed the carbon nano-onion embedded metal–organic frameworks (CMOF-199) characterized by a higher surface area about 1196.3 m2 g−1 and with 2.890 nm as particle size. Characterization of CMOF-199 with XRD, TEM, TGA, and FTIR proved its crystalline form and nano-size particle, thermal stability, and the presence of abundance function groups, respectively. Adsorption of Cd+2 onto CMOF-199 was studied and showed that optimum adsorption conditions were achieved at 0.75 g l−1 as adsorbent dosage, pH = 5, and after 40-min contact shaking time. CMOF-199 exhibited t h e max imum Langmu i r a d s o r p t i o n c a p a c i t y (113.3 mg g−1) for Cd+2 at 40 °C. The adsorption kinetic studies showed that pseudo-second kinetic models are the accepted mechanism while thermodynamic parameters indicated that the adsorption of Cd+2 by CMOF-199 is a favorable, spontaneous, and endothermic process.

referenceMentions.context: Carbon nanostructures are used in different applications (Ghalkhani et al. 2019; Hu et al. 2019; Lim et al. 2019; Hong-Shan et al. 2019; Shang et al. 2019).

Another classification for carbon nanostructure is based on empty space nanoforms such as nanohornes, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), and fullerene while carbon nano-onions (CNOs), carbon dots (C-dots), nanodiamond, and graphene were considered as a second morphological type without internal spaces (Georgakilas et al. 2015).
CNOs were used in different fields of applications such as biological applications (Giordani et al. 2014), catalysis (Shi et al.
2014), catalysis (Shi et al. 2016), energy storage (Ratajczak et al.
2016), energy storage (Ratajczak et al. 2019), anti-adhesion (Liang et al.
2019), anti-adhesion (Liang et al. 2018), electronics (Olariu et al.
2018), electronics (Olariu et al. 2017), conversion of energy (Plonska-Brzezinska and Echegoyen 2013), sensors (Wu et al.
2017), conversion of energy (Plonska-Brzezinska and Echegoyen 2013), sensors (Wu et al.

2010), hyper lubricants (Joly-Pottuz et al. 2010), and adsorption (Megan et al.

Many disadvantages for carbon nanomaterial (CNM) applications include the difficulty in separation of CNMs after treatment, toxicity effects in plants and terrestrial including ecosystem effects on epigenetics, gene expression, oxidative stress (Jordan et al. 2018), and the ability to form larger particles due to aggregations.

Attempts were introduced to enhance the application conditions of CNMs such as the formation of C-dots/chitosan composite (Wang et al. 2015), composites of carbon nano-onions with emeraldine polyaniline (Plonska-Brzezinska et al.
2015), composites of carbon nano-onions with emeraldine polyaniline (Plonska-Brzezinska et al. 2012), and carbon nanomaterial modified metal–organic frameworks (Xu et al.
2012), and carbon nanomaterial modified metal–organic frameworks (Xu et al. 2016; Farid et al. 2018).
2012), and carbon nanomaterial modified metal–organic frameworks (Xu et al. 2016; Farid et al. 2018).

Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are highly porous crystalline hybrid materials prepared from the interaction between the metal ions and multidentate organic compounds forming a three-dimensional structure characterized by high surface areas, up to 5200 m(2) g (Ben et al. 2009).
Currently, MOFs have been the subjects of many application fields such as adsorption (Wang et al. 2017), catalysis (Wang and Li 2017), energy storage (Zhang et al.
2017), catalysis (Wang and Li 2017), energy storage (Zhang et al.
2017), catalysis (Wang and Li 2017), energy storage (Zhang et al. 2018), storage of gas (Li et al.
2018), storage of gas (Li et al. 2018), drug delivery (Ke et al.
2018), drug delivery (Ke et al. 2018), and optics (Du and Zhang 2013).
Cadmium is a highly toxic heavy metal causing pancreatic cancer, renal failure (Davis et al. 2006), osteoporosis (Xu et al.
2014), hypertension (Gallagher and Meliker 2010), and diabetes (Edwards and Prozialeck 2009).
2014), hypertension (Gallagher and Meliker 2010), and diabetes (Edwards and Prozialeck 2009).
Cadmium is still used in different industries such as solar photocatalysis (Giacopetti and Satta 2018), yellow pigments (Kamran et al.

Cadmium is still used in different industries such as solar photocatalysis (Giacopetti and Satta 2018), yellow pigments (Kamran et al. 2017; Bilgin et al. 2018), phosphatic fertilizers, metal coating, batteries, plastics, and incineration of solid wastes containing cadmium (Fei et al.

Cadmium is still used in different industries such as solar photocatalysis (Giacopetti and Satta 2018), yellow pigments (Kamran et al. 2017; Bilgin et al. 2018), phosphatic fertilizers, metal coating, batteries, plastics, and incineration of solid wastes containing cadmium (Fei et al.
2018), phosphatic fertilizers, metal coating, batteries, plastics, and incineration of solid wastes containing cadmium (Fei et al. 2018).
Adsorption is still one of the most efficient, simplest, and fastest methods for the removal of organic and inorganic pollutants fromwater (Bashir et al. 2018).
pHPZC is the point at which pHfinal = pHinitial (Foo and Hameed 2012; Hassan et al. 2017).

The linear model of the Langmuir equation (Langmuir 1916) is derived as
Freundlich isotherm describes the reversible and non-ideal adsorption process (Freundlich 1906).
Temkin isotherm postulates that the heat of adsorption of all molecules in the layer would decrease linearly with surface coverage due to adsorbent–adsorbate interactions (Foo and Hameed 2012).
The linear model is expressed by the following equation (Inyinbor et al. 2016):
The mean adsorption energy (EDR, kJ mol ) can be calculated by the following equation (Banerjee and Chattopadhyaya 2017):

CNO showed thermal stability up to 620 °C, and the weight loss at 800 °C (about 89%) may be related to the oxidation of surface graphitic curved layers and thermal decomposition continued till 98% at about 1000 °C due to core oxidation of the spheres (Zhang 2006).

MOF-199 predicted the second stage of decomposition at 250–350 °C with weight loss of about 59% which may be related to –OH and a portion of organic framework decomposition (Ghiamaty et al. 2016) and that also coincides with the presence of 88% 1,3,5benzenetricarboxylic acid as MOF-199 constituent.

The presence of organic ligand (H3BTC) in MOF-199 can be proved by the appearance of sharp bands at 768, 1251, 1452, and 1630 cm which are related to C–H bending vibrations and C=C stretching vibration of the aromatic benzene ring (Fang et al. 2017).
At lower pH values, the R% of Cd is low which may be related to the protonation of active sites on the solid surface of adsorbents (Sohrabi 2014).

At pH > pHPZC, the decrease in adsorption of cadmium may be also related to the repulsion between the negatively charged solid surface and negatively charged cadmium complex ions (Moradi et al. 2016; Yusof et al. 2018).

At pH > pHPZC, the decrease in adsorption of cadmium may be also related to the repulsion between the negatively charged solid surface and negatively charged cadmium complex ions (Moradi et al. 2016; Yusof et al. 2018).
This can be related to the homogeneous distribution of active sites on solid adsorbent surfaces (Li et al. 2016).

In the case of EDR between 8 and 16 kJ mol , the adsorption is chemical ion exchange process and the physical adsorption force proved when EDR less than 8 kJ mol −1 (Rafatullah et al. 2009; Banerjee and Chattopadhyaya 2017).

In the case of EDR between 8 and 16 kJ mol , the adsorption is chemical ion exchange process and the physical adsorption force proved when EDR less than 8 kJ mol −1 (Rafatullah et al. 2009; Banerjee and Chattopadhyaya 2017).

To evaluate the efficiency of the recent solid adsorbents for removal of Cd through adsorption process, the maximum adsorption capacity and adsorption conditions for CMOF-199 were compared with other reported solid adsorbents (Kataria and Garg 2018; Luo et al. 2013; Chen et al. 2014; Megan et al. 2012; Chen et al. 2018; Gupta and Nayak 2012; Lia et al. 2003) published in previous articles (Table 5).

metadata.abstractText: Carbon nano-onions (CNOs), metal–organic frameworks (MOF-199), and carbon nano-onion embedded metal–organic frameworks (CMOF-199) were synthesized from garlic peels as a green source of carbon atoms while MOF-199 was prepared by solvothermal interaction between 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid and copper nitrate trihydrate. All the prepared solid materials were characterized by nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherm, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), energy-dispersive Xray (EDX), X-ray diffraction (XRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), point of zero charge (pHPZC), and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). Adsorption of cadmium ions from aqueous solution was investigated onto all prepared solid materials considering different application conditions such as adsorbent dosage, pH, contact time, initial concentration of Cd , and temperature. Adsorption of Cd was investigated by Langmuir, Freundlich, Temkin, and Dubinin–Radhushkevich adsorption isotherm models. Maximum adsorption capacity (113.3 mg g) was achieved by CMOF-199 at 40 °C. The adsorption of Cd obeys pseudo-second-order kinetic model. Thermodynamic studies confirmed that the adsorption process is spontaneous, favorable, endothermic, and physisorption. Adsorption results proved that carbon nano-onion embedded metal–organic frameworks are promising solid adsorbents for cadmium ion adsorption.
